summary: Email correspondence between prosecutors and defense attorneys regarding the inadvertent production of unmarked confidential discovery materials in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, including instructions to delete and replace documents, and coordination for hard drive delivery.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, coordinating receipt of discovery materials and hard drives with prosecutors.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on emails regarding discovery production and hard drive logistics.

connections.description: Co-defense attorneys representing Ghislaine Maxwell, both addressed on discovery materials and correspondence.

events.title: Discovery Production with Confidentiality Error
events.description: Prosecutors inadvertently produced ten documents without 'Confidential' stamps; materials related to unsealing motions in civil cases 15 Civ. 7433 and 17 Civ. 0616.

events.title: Correction of Confidential Designation
events.description: Prosecutors send updated cover letter and corrected documents with proper 'Confidential' designation, instructing defense to delete old versions.

events.title: Hard Drive Delivery Coordination
events.description: Defense delivers 2TB hard drives to prosecutors for loading discovery materials; prosecutors confirm receipt and plan for production.

keyFacts: Prosecutors inadvertently produced ten discovery documents without proper 'Confidential' stamps in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The materials pertained to unsealing motions in related civil cases: 15 Civ. 7433 (RWS) and 17 Civ. 0616 (SN).
Defense attorneys Christian Everdell and Mark S. Cohen were coordinating receipt of discovery via physical hard drives delivered to prosecutors.
Prosecutors instructed the defense to delete unmarked versions and replace them with correctly marked confidential documents.
The correspondence reveals ongoing discovery production efforts in August 2020 ahead of Maxwell's trial.
